content: The Gas Price Spike Act of 2012, also known as the Windfall Profits Tax, imposes a tax on crude oil, natural gas, and related products under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Gas Price Spike Act of 2012, also known as the Windfall Profits Tax, imposes an excise tax on the sale of crude oil, natural gas, or other taxable products in the United States. The tax is based on the windfall profit, which is the profit exceeding a reasonable amount, with an applicable percentage determined based on the profit margin. The Windfall Profits Tax imposes an excise tax on the sale of taxable products in the US based on the profit margin exceeding a reasonable amount. The tax percentage varies from 25% to 100% depending on the profit margin. The term 'reasonable profit' is determined by the Reasonable Profits Board. The seller is liable for paying the taxes imposed. Chapter 56 introduces a Windfall Profit tax on crude oil and refined petroleum products. The effective date for the amendments is upon enactment. Section 3 offers a credit for purchasing fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles under the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code offers a tax credit for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles based on fuel efficiency. The credit amount ranges from $3,000 to $6,000 depending on the vehicle's fuel economy. The tax credit for purchasing qualified passenger vehicles ranges from $3,000 to $6,000 based on fuel efficiency. Vehicles within the 10 percent most fuel-efficient range have a fuel economy equal to or greater than the lowest fuel economy of the top 10 percent of vehicles sold in the previous year. The 5 and 10 percent most fuel-efficient ranges are determined separately. The most fuel-efficient ranges for trucks, SUVs, and other qualified vehicles are determined separately. The Secretary publishes the 5 and 10 percent most fuel-efficient ranges at the beginning of each calendar year. The term "qualified automobile" refers to any vehicle purchased after a certain date. The credit for a qualified automobile applies to vehicles purchased after a certain date, assembled in the US under a collective bargaining agreement, with personal nonbusiness use, and fuel economy within the top 10 percent range. Fuel economy is determined according to section 4064, and the basis of the property is reduced by the amount of the credit. No credit allowed for property used outside the United States. Amend table of sections for subpart A. Section 25E allows for the purchase of fuel-efficient American-made passenger vehicles. The amendments apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, Section 4 addresses mass transit fare reductions during gas price spikes. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants to mass transit systems to reduce passenger fares. Grants must be used for fare reductions applied equally to all passengers. The definition of mass transit system includes buses and commuter rail. Appropriations are authorized based on excess revenues from the previous fiscal year. The Secretary of Transportation may provide grants to mass transit systems for fare reductions. Grants must be used equally for all passengers. Amounts authorized for fuel-efficient vehicles and windfall profit on oil remain available until expended. SEC. 5. REASONABLE PROFITS BOARD. The Reasonable Profits Board is established as an independent board to make profit determinations for the Internal Revenue Code. It consists of 3 members appointed by the President for a 3-year term, with no financial interests in relevant businesses. The Reasonable Profits Board consists of 3 members appointed by the President for a 3-year term. Board members are paid at a rate equal to the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule and receive travel expenses. The Board appoints a Director with no financial interests in relevant businesses. The Director of the Reasonable Profits Board is paid at the rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional personnel without following standard appointment procedures and pay regulations. The Reasonable Profits Board can request personnel from federal agencies for assistance and the Comptroller General can also provide support. The Board has the authority to procure temporary services of experts or consultants as needed. The Board may lease space and acquire personal property to the extent that funds are available, with necessary funds authorized to be appropriated for this purpose.
